Award.AwardTitle: MSUB Robert Noyce Scholarship Track Phase 1

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: Montana State University Billings is providing Robert Noyce scholarships and unique training for secondary science and mathematics teacher candidates to prepare them to effectively deliver content in a culturally sensitive manner for high-need and sometimes, reluctant learners. This effort is focused on providing 18 highly qualified teachers (12 undergraduates and 6 career changers) for high-need rural Montana school districts on or near American Indian reservations, where data shows low matriculation rates for STEM majors. Six undergraduates will receive schorships in year 1 and 6 in year 2. Three professionals will receive scholarships in year 1 and 3 in year 2. Using state science standards based on practices that embed inquiry-based learning pedagogy, this Noyce Scholarship Track Phase I project trains teachers to engage secondary students with methods that keep the students interested and motivated to continue STEM learning. These training methods have broad applicability to other rural situations and will develop a stronger pipeline of students from these rural schools to become STEM majors. The MSUB teacher-training program builds on six unique courses in mathematics and sciences in combination with a Noyce teacher cohort seminar that focuses on the needs of reluctant learners. Previous research suggests that students on or near American Indian reservations need greater cultural connections with STEM subjects and this program is training teachers to frame instruction in new ways to help make this connection. This is an important intellectual contribution from this project. To help ensure that the Noyce graduates succeed at the beginning of their teaching career, this project mentors them during their initial years of teaching using specially trained success coaches and continuing professional development.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Federal Grant 1339919, Montana State University Billings (MSUB) Robert Noyce Scholarship Track Phase 1 (RNST1) has been active from 2013 - 2019. Initially, it was funded to support 18 Scholars. As of September 2019, there are 14 Scholars who are now teaching in various Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (STEM) fields in high-need schools in Montana, Wyoming, and Colorado.  MSUB's primary objective for the RNST1 project was to train 12 STEM students and 6 STEM professionals to become secondary teachers serving in high-need schools in Montana, particularly those on or near American Indian reservations. Currently, 62% of these participants teach biology, 38% teach earth science, 44% chemistry, 31% physics, and 6% mathematics. Many Scholars taught in multiple subjects and 5 Scholars noted that they taught other courses, including Physical Science and Health Sciences. Although these Noyce Scholars are teaching STEM subjects in high-need schools, MSUB did not achieve our secondary objective of placing the majority of Scholars in rural schools on or near reservations.

Surveys of Noyce Scholars indicate a number of RNST1 successes. Participants were provided a wide array of seminars, conferences, courses and workshops preparing them to teach reluctant learners in high-need or rural areas, and these were indicated in the survey as the most valuable of all RNST1 supports. Scholars noted the sense of community and the networking opportunities and relationships RNST1 provided. Noyce Scholars were given many opportunities for participating in events on campus, throughout the state, and in the greater STEM community. They were judges in the Billings and State Science Fairs. Many were presenters at various conferences, including the School Sciences and Mathematics Conference and the National Science Teachers Association. Participants also noted the strength of their STEM coursework, encouragement and support from their Noyce faculty advisors, and the ease with which most of them found employment.

A number of accomplishments occurred during the Final Reporting Period, October 1, 2018 to September 30, 2019. First, Shelly Stanton held a Google Technology conference for the Scholars on February 23, 2019 at MSUB. Shelly is a Technology Integration Specialist for the Billings Public Schools. Shelly supports teachers as they integrate technology into their classrooms in purposeful ways. Her mission is for students to create, not consume, while using technology for thinking, sharing, creating and learning. Second, several Scholars attended a 4-day workshop in Jackson, Wyoming from June 24 - 27, 2019 to learn about various science-teaching techniques. This workshop was hosted by the Teton Science Schools. Third, Noyce Scholars were provided grants in August 2019 to help with materials and/or projects for their classrooms. Scholars filled out a Survey to qualify for this grant. Fourth, the MSUB website and the MSUB Facebook page for the Noyce Scholar Program enhanced the lives of the Scholars as teachers and provided the Scholars the necessary support to improve their teaching skills.
